Programmer University of Alaska Fairbanks (UAF - GINA) October 2002  –  August 2010  (7 years 11 months) Fairbanks, Alaska My primary project was SwathViewer, a Java applet similar to Google Earth but with more of a GIS flavor (try it: http://sv.gina.alaska.edu). Existing tools could not handle the university's volume of imagery nor the cartographic challenges of the polar region. Over time I developed SwathViewer into a very capable GIS tool, and it has since been licensed to a manufacturer of satellite receiving stations. 
 
I developed a tool to construct elevation data from imagery acquired by the Magellan Venus mission. The imagery was very noisy due to peculiarities of the sensor. I developed novel filtration techniques and other algorithmic optimizations which vastly improved performance of an existing technique. The result was an elevation dataset with resolution an order of magnitude higher than the previous altimetry data.

My goal is to design chips for complex ecosystems that are both valued in the world, and challenging in their scope and complexity. Importantly, I desire to work on teams whose individuals are eager to share their own knowledge and experiences as well as absorb the best from others. 
 
I enjoy my current employment to a great degree. Although I am always open to workplaces that can be even better, please understand that an offer needs to be quite spectacular to be worth discussing. The same standard applies to any job offer that I would recommend.

Experience Rotation Engineer Intel Corporation July 2014  – Present (1 year 2 months) Chandler, AZ As part of Intel's rotation engineer program, completing three six month rotations within the company. Currently starting third rotation; seeking final placement within Intel by December 31st. 
 
First Rotation: AVX process engineer at Fab 32 (Chandler, AZ). 
• Gained experience in fab/manufacturing operations, data queries/analysis, troubleshooting issues, and sustaining a challenging new metal deposition toolset.  
• Improved tool availability by 3.5% by monitoring and addressing excursion prevention issues. 
• Received Department Award for efforts to sustain and improve toolset.  
 
Second rotation: SPTD Litho Development Engineer (Chandler, AZ).  
• Collaborated with Substrate Packaging Technology Development team to develop lithography bias models to optimize etch and substrate yields.  
• Ran DOEs to characterize key process parameters (alignment, bias, overlay). 
 
Third rotation: Silicon Photonics Device Integration Engineer (Santa Clara, CA). 
• Working with team of photonics designers, division integration engineers, and fab process/integration engineers to deliver a manufacturable, reliable process for an integrated silicon photonics chip.  
• Leveraging and building upon my experience in photonics and manufacturing to bridge between design needs and fab's capabilities. Used finite element modeling (COMSOL) to study behavior of optical resonators during biosensing experiments. Defended my thesis "Developing improved silica materials and devices for integrated optics applications" on May 21, 2014.
